field_reports.description:
Overview:
An earthquake with a magnitude of 8.8 at a depth of 20.69 km has occurred at 136 km east-southeast of Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky, Russia, as reported by the National Earthquake Information Center (NEIC) of the USGS on July 29, 2025 08:24 local time（JST）.
A tsunami warning of up to 3 meters has been issued along Japan's Pacific coast from Hokkaido to Wakayama. Officials are calling on people to stay evacuated until all alerts are lifted despite the hot weather. Tsunami have been observed over wide areas along the coast, including a 1.3-meter wave at Kuji Port in Iwate Prefecture.（As of 16:30 local time on 30 July 2025）
The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded the tsunami warning that had been issued for the Pacific coasts of Hokkaido and Tohoku to a tsunami advisory at 20:45 local time on 30 July. But people across the country are urged to stay cautious, as the tsunami advisories remain in place from Hokkaido to Okinawa.

Impact:
Tsunami waves have reached several Pacific coastal areas of Japan after the earthquake.

  • A 1.3-meter tsunami was recorded at Kuji Port in Iwate prefecture, while a 80 centimeter wave was observed at Nemuro, Hokkaido and 70 centimeter tsunami at Ishinomaki Port in Miyagi.
  • High waves have also been observed in the Tohoku and Kanto regions. A 30 centimeter wave was recorded at Yokohama Port.

Runways at Sendai Airport in Japan's northeast have been closed after an earthquake in Russia triggered tsunami warnings.

  • The transport ministry said the runway shutdown began around 9:40 a.m., and that some flights bound for the major coastal hub were rerouted.
  • Flights to and from the airport were suspended. Airlines are urging customers to stay updated by checking their websites.
field_reports.summary: JPN: Tsunami - 07-2025 - Tsunami warning issued for Japan's Pacific coast triggered by the M8.8 earthquake in Kamchatka Peninsula, Russia

results.name: JPN: Tsunami - 07-2025 - Tsunami warning issued for Japan's Pacific coast triggered by the M8.8 earthquake in Kamchatka Peninsula, Russia

A tsunami warning of up to 3 meters has been issued along Japan's Pacific coast from Hokkaido to Wakayama. Officials are calling on people to stay evacuated until all alerts are lifted despite the hot weather. Tsunami have been observed over wide areas along the coast, including a 1.3-meter wave at Kuji Port in Iwate Prefecture.（As of 16:30 local time on 30 July 2025）

Impact:

  • A 1.3-meter tsunami was recorded at Kuji Port in Iwate prefecture, while a 80 centimeter wave was observed at Nemuro, Hokkaido and 70 centimeter tsunami at Ishinomaki Port in Miyagi.

Runways at Sendai Airport in Japan's northeast have been closed after an earthquake in Russia triggered tsunami warnings.

  • Flights to and from the airport were suspended. Airlines are urging customers to stay updated by checking their websites.

field_reports.description: Seismic activity has been very active around the area since the end of June and a magnitude 5.5 (in the Japanese intensity scare level 6 lower) earthquake struck near the Tokara Islands in Kagoshima Prefecture at 4:13 p.m on 3 July 2025. So far there has been no report of casualties. About 700 people live on the 12 Tokara islands, and some of the residents have been evacuating voluntarily to the mainland.
field_reports.summary: JPN: Earthquake - 07-2025 - Earthquake Centered in the Adjacent Sea of Tokara Islands

results.name: JPN: Earthquake - 07-2025 - Earthquake Centered in the Adjacent Sea of Tokara Islands
results.summary: Seismic activity has been very active around the area since the end of June and a magnitude 5.5 (in the Japanese intensity scare level 6 lower) earthquake struck near the Tokara Islands in Kagoshima Prefecture at 4:13 p.m on 3 July 2025. So far there has been no report of casualties. About 700 people live on the 12 Tokara islands, and some of the residents have been evacuating voluntarily to the mainland.

field_reports.description:
On February 26, 2025, a significant wildfire broke out in the forested areas of Ofunato City, Iwate Prefecture, northeastern Japan. The fire caused extensive damage, affecting over 2,100 hectares of the forest land. As of the latest reports, at least 84 buildings have been damaged and one fatality has been confirmed. The exact cause of the fire is still under investigation.

Evacuation orders were issued for approximately 1,896 households, affecting 4,596 people across 17 districts.

results.name: JPN: Fire - 02-2025 - Wildfire in Iwate
results.summary:
On February 26, 2025, a significant wildfire broke out in the forested areas of Ofunato City, Iwate Prefecture, northeastern Japan. The fire caused extensive damage, affecting over 2,100 hectares of the forest land. As of the latest reports, at least 84 buildings have been damaged and one fatality has been confirmed. The exact cause of the fire is still under investigation.

Evacuation orders were issued for approximately 1,896 households, affecting 4,596 people across 17 districts.

field_reports.description:
On 8 August 2024 at 16:43 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.1 magnitude earthquake struck southwestern Japan, with its epicenter in the Hyuganada sea off the coast of Miyazaki Prefecture, at a depth of 30km. Strong tremors were observed in many places in the Kyushu region, and the Meteorological Agency has issued a tsunami warning/advisory for the coastal areas of Miyazaki, Kochi, Oita, Kagoshima and Ehime prefectures. The tsunami reached a height of 50cm in the coastal areas, but no direct damage from the tsunami was reported as of 18:45.

One house has collapsed in Kagoshima Prefecture as a result of the earthquake, and flights to and from Miyazaki Airport and some highways are currently suspended. However, there have been no reports of power or water cuts or abnormalities at nuclear facilities. The number of casualties is still unknown, but three injuries have been reported in Miyazaki and Kumamoto prefectures as of 19:00. The Japan Meteorological Agency is calling for caution in the coming week in the strong level of earthquakes.

 

JRCS Headquarters have been closely monitoring the situation in contact with local chapters in the affected areas.
field_reports.summary: JPN: Earthquake - 08-2024 - Earthquake hit Miyazaki Prefecture

results.name: JPN: Earthquake - 08-2024 - Earthquake hit Miyazaki Prefecture

field_reports.description:
On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. As of 1 February, 1,568 aftershocks have followed the main shock. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area. One month passed since the earthquake and local transportation system have been gradually restored, but still lifeline including water, electricity are cut off in disastrous areas. 

Impacts
As of 31 January, the local government confirmed 238 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns including 15 disaster-related deaths, and 19 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 1,288 people were injured, 26,451 houses were damaged, and 14,648 people are evacuated to 521 evacuation centers. 41,590 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the water supplies, and 2,300 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.


Challenges
The search efforts and removing the rubble by the fire departments, the national defense forces, and polices are ongoing through areas near the epicenter of the earthquake, but 19 people are still unaccounted for, and searching in the rain and snow can be difficult.

On 9 January, Ishikawa Prefecture announced its first “disaster-related deaths” – people who died either of injuries or illnesses after having evacuated. Now the total number is 15. It urgently needs to immediately take preventative measures in areas impacted by the earthquake. 

Still many people are to stay at evacuation centres. Since the water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people is still high. COVID19 and flu were confirmed. 

Heavy Rain and snow for some parts of the affected area continuously, and temperatures are expected to drop, increasing the risk of hypothermia in the evacuation centres and the danger of landslides is warned in the affected area.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. As of 25 January, 1,510 aftershocks have followed the main shock. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area. Four weeks passed since the earthquake and local transportation system have been gradually restored, but still lifeline including water, electricity are cut off in disastrous areas.

Impacts
As of 25 January, the local government confirmed 233 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns including 15 disaster-related deaths, and 19 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 1,284 people were injured, 16,423 houses were damaged, and 15,152 people are evacuated to 457 evacuation centers. 45,380 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the water supplies, and 4,300 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.

Challenges
The search efforts and removing the rubble by the fire departments, the national defense forces, and polices are ongoing through areas near the epicenter of the earthquake, but 19 people are still unaccounted for, and searching in the rain and snow can be difficult.

On 9 January, Ishikawa Prefecture announced its first “disaster-related deaths” – people who died either of injuries or illnesses after having evacuated. Now the total number is 15. It urgently needs to immediately take preventative measures in areas impacted by the earthquake. 

Still many people are to stay at evacuation centres. Since the water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people is still high. COVID19 and flu were confirmed.

Heavy Rain and snow for some parts of the affected area continuously, and temperatures are expected to drop, increasing the risk of hypothermia in the evacuation centres and the danger of landslides is warned in the affected area.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. As of 18 January, 1,444 aftershocks have followed the main shock. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area..

 

Impacts

As of 18 January, the local government confirmed 232 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns including 14 disaster-related deaths, and 22 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 1,009 people were injured, 9,625 houses were damaged, and 17,141 people are evacuated to 434 evacuation centers. 51,030 houses in Ishikawa, and 130 houses in Toyama prefectures are cut from the water supplies, and 7,500 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.

 

Challenges

The search efforts and removing the rubble by the fire departments, the national defense forces, and polices are ongoing through areas near the epicenter of the earthquake, but over 20 people are still unaccounted for, and searching in the rain can be difficult, as there is a risk that buildings that have become heavy with water will collapse, and that the footing can become slippery.　On 9 January, Ishikawa Prefecture announced its first “disaster-related deaths” – people who died either of injuries or illnesses after having evacuated. It urgently needs to immediately take preventative measures in areas impacted by the earthquake. Despite of the hard efforts by the government and NGOs for recovery of roads and distribution of water, food and non-food items, some districts in Wajima city, Suzu city, are still remained to be isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply. The water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, concerning the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people.

Rain and snow are forecast for some parts of the affected area continuously, and temperatures are expected to drop, increasing the risk of hypothermia in the evacuation centres and the danger of landslides is warned in the affected area.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area. According to the Japan Nuclear Regulation Authority, no issues have been found with reactors at nuclear power plants in the affected area, including the Shika Nuclear Power Plant located in Ishikawa Prefecture. As of 11 January, 1,320 aftershocks have followed the main shock.

Impacts

As of 11 January, the local government confirmed 213 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns including eight “disaster-related deaths”, and 37 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 524 people were injured, 3,877 houses were damaged, and 24,038 people are evacuated to 415 evacuation centers. 58,909 houses in Ishikawa, and 1,780 houses in Toyama prefectures are cut from the water supplies, and 13,600 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.

Challenges

The search and rescue efforts by the fire departments and the national defense forces are still ongoing through areas near the epicenter of the earthquake even more than 10 days passed after the quake, and the death toll is continuing to rise. On 9 January, Ishikawa Prefecture announced its first “disaster-related deaths” – people who died either of injuries or illnesses after having evacuated. It urgently needs to immediately take preventative measures in areas impacted by the earthquake. As of 11 January, despite of the hard efforts by the government and NGOs for recovery of roads and distribution of water, food and non-food items, at least 22 districts staying 2,562 residents in Wajima city, Suzu city, and Noto town are still remained to be isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply. The water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, concerning the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people. 

Heavy and snow are forecast for some parts of the affected area from 12 January, and temperatures are expected to drop, increasing the risk of hypothermia in the evacuation centres and the danger of landslides is warned in the affected area.

contacts.title: Officer, International Relief Division, International Department

field_reports.description:
On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area. According to the Japan Nuclear Regulation Authority, no issues have been found with reactors at nuclear power plants in the affected area, including the Shika Nuclear Power Plant located in Ishikawa Prefecture. As of 10 January, 1,296 aftershocks have followed the main shock.

 

Impacts

As of 10 January, the local government confirmed 203 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns, and 52 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 523 people were injured, 3,176 houses were damaged, and 25,770 people are evacuated to 405 evacuation centers. 58,738 houses in Ishikawa, and 3,590 houses in Toyama prefectures are cut from the water supplies, and 14,900 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.

 

Challenges

The search and rescue efforts by the fire departments and the national defense forces are still ongoing through areas near the epicenter of the earthquake even more than 10 days passed after the quake, and the death toll is continuing to rise. On 9 January, Ishikawa Prefecture announced its first “disaster-related deaths” – people who died either of injuries or illnesses after having evacuated. It urgently needs to immediately take preventative measures in areas impacted by the earthquake. As of 10 January, despite of the hard efforts by the government and NGOs for recovery of roads and distribution of water, food and non-food items, at least 22 districts staying 3,123 residents in Wajima city, Suzu city, Nanao city, Anamizu town and Noto town are still remained to be isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply. The water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, concerning the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people.

Rain and snow are forecast for some parts of the affected area from 12 January, and temperatures are expected to drop. On 11 January morning, the coldest temperature was recorded in the affected areas this winter, increasing the risk of hypothermia in the evacuation centres.

As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area. According to the Japan Nuclear Regulation Authority, no issues have been found with reactors at nuclear power plants in the affected area, including the Shika Nuclear Power Plant located in Ishikawa Prefecture. As of 9 January, 1,262 aftershocks have followed the main shock.

Impacts
As of 9 January, the local government confirmed 202 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns, and 102 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 521 people were injured, 2,043 houses were damaged, and 26,284 people are evacuated to 412 evacuation centers. 59,334 houses in Ishikawa, Toyama prefecture are cut from the water supplies, and 15,500 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.


Challenges
As of 10 January, the search and rescue efforts by the fire departments and the national defense forces are still ongoing through areas near the epicenter of the earthquake even more than 9 days passed after the quake, and the death toll is continuing to rise. On 9 January, Ishikawa Prefecture announced its first “disaster-related deaths” – people who died either of injuries or illnesses after having evacuated. It urgently needs to immediately take preventative measures in areas impacted by the earthquake. Despite of the hard efforts by the government and NGOs for recovery of roads and distribution of water, food and non-food items, at least 22 districts staying 3,123 residents in Wajima city, Suzu city, Nanao city, Anamizu town and Noto town are still remained to be isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply. The water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, concerning the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people.

The local meteorological observatory announced a heavy rain warning in the affected area on 10 January, and the danger of landslides is warned until evening.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area. According to the Japan Nuclear Regulation Authority, no issues have been found with reactors at nuclear power plants in the affected area, including the Shika Nuclear Power Plant located in Ishikawa Prefecture. As of 8 January, 1,219 aftershocks have followed the main shock.


Impacts
As of 8 January, the local government confirmed 168 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns, and 323 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 521 people were injured, 1,889 houses were damaged, and 28,301 people are evacuated to 403 evacuation centers. 70,395 houses in Ishikawa, Toyama and Niigata prefectures are cut from the water supplies, and 18,000 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.


Challenges
As of 8 January, the search and rescue efforts by the fire departments and the national defence forces are still ongoing even more than one week passed after the quake. Despite of the hard efforts by the government and NGOs for recovery of roads and distribution of water, food and non-food items, at least 24 districts staying 3,345 residents in Wajima city, Suzu city, Nanao city, Anamizu town and Noto town are still remained to be isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply. The water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, concerning the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people. Total 197 Disaster Medical Assistance Team(DMAT)s from all over Japan including ones from Japanese Red Cross Society are supporting the local health systems in the affected areas. The affected area got around 10 cm of snow on 7 January, and the severe cold with minus degrees is expected on 9 January, increasing the risk of hypothermia in the evacuation centres.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. The massive quake collapsed many houses trapping residences in the most affected area nearby the epicentre such as Wajima city, Suzu city, Noto town located in northern part of the peninsula. The quake caused fires in some cities which burnt down hundreds of houses. The tsunami reached coastal areas just after the earthquake, and damaged at least 120 hectares in Suzu City and Noto town. The electric power and water supplies were cut, and the communications of mobile phones, landlines and internet were disrupted in the affected area. The roads in the affected area were severely damaged by the quake, and some landslides caused by the quake also prevented the access to/within the affected area. According to the Japan Nuclear Regulation Authority, no issues have been found with reactors at nuclear power plants in the affected area, including the Shika Nuclear Power Plant located in Ishikawa Prefecture. As of 6 January, 1,040 aftershocks have followed the main shock.

Impacts

As of 6 January, the local government confirmed 100 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/towns, and 210 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for. In Ishikawa and other surrounding prefectures, the local governments confirmed totally 568 people were injured, 1,280 houses were damaged, and 31,628 people are evacuated to 374 evacuation centers. 72,203 houses in Ishikawa, Toyama and Niigata prefectures are cut from the water supplies, and 23,900 houses in Ishikawa prefecture are cut from the electric power supplies.

Challenges

As of 6 January, the search and rescue efforts by the fire departments and the national defence forces are still ongoing even more than 72 hours passed after the quake. Despite of the hard efforts by the government and NGOs for recovery of roads and distribution of water, food and non-food items, some districts in Wajima city, Suzu city, Nanao city, Anamizu town and Noto town are still remained to be isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply. The water, sanitation and hygiene capacities in the evacuation centres are limited, concerning the risk of communicable diseases among the evacuated people. Total 126 Disaster Medical Assistance Team(DMAT)s from all over Japan including ones from Japanese Red Cross Society are supporting the local health systems in the affected areas. A heavy snow is expected from 7 January, which could be obstacle to relief activities.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued.
As of 7:30 on 5 January, the local government confirmed 84 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City, Nanao City and other cities/districts. On top of this, 179 people in Ishikawa prefecture remain unaccounted for.

The tsunami damaged at least 100 hectares in Suzu City and Noto City. Power and water supplies were still cut, communications were disrupted and dozens of houses collapsed. 

Some districts are isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply.

Strong Rain hit to Noto region and heavy snow is expected from 7 January, which could be obstacle to relief activities.

The quake caused fires in some cities and it is estimated that hundreds of houses were burnt down. More than 34,000 people remained in evacuation centres. According to the local government, toilet and sanitation situation is particularly critical.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued.
As of 15:00 on 3 January, the local government confirmed 65 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City, Nanao City and other cities/districts, with the number of deaths feared to rise.

The tsunami damaged at least 100 hectares in Suzu City and Noto City. Power and water supplies were still cut, communications were disrupted and dozens of houses collapsed. 

Some districts are isolated with roads cut off and food, water, blanket and fuel, basic needs are still in short supply.

Rain is expected in the Noto region until the early hours of 4 January, which could lead to landslides.

The quake caused fires in some cities and it is estimated that hundreds of houses were burnt down. More than 33,000 people remained in evacuation centres. According to the local government, toilet and sanitation situation is particularly critical.

According to the Japan Nuclear Regulation Authority, no issues have been found with reactors at nuclear power plants in the affected area, including the Shika nuclear power plant in Ishikawa Prefecture.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow (16 km deep), strong tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued.
As of 17:00 on 2 January, the local government confirmed 48 deaths in Wajima City, Suzu City and other cities/districts, with the number of deaths feared to rise.
As a result of the quake, power and water supplies were cut, communications were disrupted and dozens of houses collapsed. The quake caused fires in some cities and it is estimated that hundreds of houses were burnt down. More than 30,000 people remained in evacuation centres on the first night of the disaster. According to the Japan Nuclear Regulation Authority, no issues have been found with reactors at nuclear power plants in the affected area, including the Shika nuclear power plant in Ishikawa Prefecture.

On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a magnitude 7.6 earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow, large tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. As a result of the quake, power and water supplies were cut, communications were disrupted and dozens of houses were reported to have collapsed. However, no direct damage from the tsunami was reported. As of 21:00, the number of casualties was still unknown and a large fire had broken out in Wajima City, Ishikawa Prefecture.

The Japanese Red Cross Society began its response immediately after the disaster, and its branches in the affected areas are working with Red Cross hospitals and Red Cross Blood Centres to assess the extent of the damage. Neighbouring branches have sent relief teams to the affected area to reinforce the response. In addition, disaster management experts of the JRCS headquarters will join the Disaster Management Team of the National Cabinet Office and begin assessments soon.

results.name: JPN: Noto Peninsula Earthquake 01-2024
results.summary:
On 1 January 2024 at 16:10 (Japan Standard Time), a magnitude 7.6 earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. As the epicentre was very shallow, large tremors were observed in many places and a tsunami warning was issued. As a result of the quake, power and water supplies were cut, communications were disrupted and hundreds of houses were reported to have collapsed.

The Japanese Red Cross Society began its response immediately after the disaster and its branches in the affected areas are working with Red Cross hospitals and Red Cross Blood Centres to assess the extent of the damage. Cross-organisational coordination, medical response and the distribution of relief goods are underway.

results.name: GDACS Orange: Japan, China TC Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 148 km/h)
results.summary: From 16/07/2021 to 18/07/2021, a Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 157 km/h) IN-FA-21 was active in NWPacific. The cyclone affects these countries: Japan, China (vulnerability Medium). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 10.015 million.

field_reports.description:
Central Japan is currently in the latter part of the summer rainy season. Atami in Shizuoka Prefecture, located about 100 km southwest of Central Tokyo, has recorded 410 mm of rain in 72 hours from Thursday to Saturday, which is 1.7 times more than the average June rainfall.

At 10:30am on Saturday 3 July (JST), torrential rain triggered mudslides. The mudslides travelled nearly two kilometres. Prefectural officials say the slides damaged at least 130 buildings including houses in their path.

Around 1,100 firefighters, police and Self-Defense Forces personnel were involved in searching for the missing while working to clear away mud and debris using heavy machinery.

Number details are still under investigation.
field_reports.summary: Mudslides triggered by heavy rain in central Japan

results.name: The Japan mudslide triggered by heavy rain

field_reports.description:
Magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit off northeast Japan at around 11:08 p.m. on Feb. 13.
The temblor registered an upper 6 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in Fukushima and Miyagi prefectures. The quake was focused off Fukushima Prefecture at a depth of about 60 kilometers.
Over 70 people were reported to get injured, but the details are not immediately clear. 
An earthquake task force was set up at the prime minister's office crisis management center.
